metadata.case_name: Petitioner v. State of Madhya Bharat

facts.text: Petitioner, a resident of Delhi, was admitted as a student of Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Medical College, Indore in July 1952, and is now studying in the third year class, B.B.S. Course.

The institution originated in 1878 as Indore Medical School by Dr. Beaumont, received assistance from rulers, renamed King Edward Memorial School in 1910, upgraded to Medical College by 1947, affiliated to University of Agra in 1948, known as Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Medical College.
In 1950, College Council requested Madhya Bharat Government to take over, accepted by resolution dated 17-3-1951, subject to arrangements for reservation of seats for nominees of States and donors.
Pre-takeover rules: Maximum 50 students per year, nominees pay Rs.1,300 capitation fee plus usual fees, self-nominees selected on merit, Madhya Bharat students exempted from capitation fees.

Post-takeover rule (1952, under which petitioner admitted): No capitation fee for bona fide residents of Madhya Bharat; others pay Rs.1,300 for nominees, Rs.1,500 for others. Bona fide resident defined as: (a) citizen with original domicile in MP not acquired elsewhere; (b) citizen original domicile not MP but acquired MP domicile and resided 5 years; (c) Pakistan migrant before 30-9-1948 intending permanent residence; (d) persons from adjacent areas with govt declaration.
Petitioner required to pay Rs.1,500 per annum capitation fee in addition to tuition fees and charges payable by all students.
Petitioner paid Rs.3,000 capitation fee for first two years, seeks refund and prohibition for current year.
Later modification post High Court decision in Rustam Mody v. State: Exemption only for bona fide residents selected for reserved seats per allocation scheme.
Allocation scheme: Seats reserved for nominees of States/donors, for MP residents, rest self-nominees; admission by competitive exam, merit within categories.

legal_issues.text: Whether the rule imposing capitation fee on non-bona fide residents of Madhya Bharat while exempting bona fide residents violates Article 15(1) as discrimination on grounds only of place of birth.
Whether the rule is discriminatory and violates Article 14 of the Constitution.
Whether the rule qualifies as 'law' under Article 13 for application of Articles 14 and 15.

petitioner_arguments.text: The rule discriminates based on place of birth by exempting Madhya Bharat students (via domicile definition equating to birth) while charging others capitation fee, violating Article 15(1).
Imposition of capitation fee on some students and not others is discriminatory without reasonable classification, violating Article 14.
Clause (d) of bona fide resident definition introduces irrational preference for foreign nationals.

respondent_arguments.text: Rule based on bona fide residence, not place of birth; residence and domicile distinct from birth; no violation of Article 15(1).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 15(1); Whicker v. Hume; Udny v. Udny

respondent_arguments.text: Classification based on residence within State reasonable to benefit local residents, aids State education objectives; valid under Article 14.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14; Article 41; State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh

respondent_arguments.text: Rule is administrative/executive order, not 'law' under Article 13, so Articles 14/15 inapplicable.
State took over subject to pre-existing conditions including capitation fee rule.

court_reasoning.text: Residence and place of birth are distinct; prohibition in Article 15(1) on discrimination based on place of birth does not extend to residence or domicile; domicile of origin not synonymous with place of birth.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Domicile means permanent home; Article 15(1) cannot be read as prohibiting discrimination based on residence.

court_reasoning.text: Regional domicile possible under Constitution as States may have different personal laws (succession, marriage); classification based on bona fide residence reasonable for State to aid local education.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object to help State residents; concession in fees ensures benefit to State; geographical classification valid.

court_reasoning.text: Clause (d) severable; even if invalid, rest valid; no need to decide as petitioner not affected.
Dissent (Jagannadhadas J.): Rule effectively based on place of birth via 'original domicile'; no concept of regional domicile in India; offends Article 15(1) and unreasonable under Article 14.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Original domicile in MP conveys place of birth; regional domicile foreign to Constitution.

holdings.text: Rule does not violate Article 15(1) as based on residence/domicile, not place of birth; classification reasonable under Article 14.
Petition dismissed; no need to decide if rule is 'law'.
Dissent: Rule unconstitutional under Articles 14 and 15(1); petition allowed.

precedents_cited.relevance: Domicile of origin not place of birth; follows father's domicile.
Domicile of birth not accurate term; distinct from place of birth.
Distinction between political status (citizenship) and civil status (domicile).

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh

precedents_cited.relevance: High Court decision leading to rule modification.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for petition; equality, non-discrimination on place of birth; directive for education; uniform civil code.

statutes_cited.name: Seventh Schedule, Concurrent List
statutes_cited.relevance: Legislative power on marriage, succession, etc., allowing potential State variations.

outcome.summary: The petition under Article 32 challenging capitation fee rule as violating Articles 14 and 15(1) fails and is dismissed. No order as to costs. (Majority view; Jagannadhadas J. dissents).

key_quotes.text: Residence and place of birth are two distinct conceptions with different connotations both in law and in fact.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes basis of classification from Article 15(1) prohibition.

key_quotes.text: The classification is thus based on a ground which has a reasonable relation to the subject-matter of the legislation.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds under Article 14 as benefiting State residents.

key_quotes.text: The phrase original domicile in Madhya Bharat is meant to convey the place of birth of the applicant in Madhya Bharat.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissent views rule as violating Article 15(1).

key_quotes.text: There has been in India up to the present moment no scope for growth of any concept of State or Provincial domicile as distinct from Indian domicile.
key_quotes.speaker: court
